Award.AwardTitle: CIF:Small:Low-rank matrix and tensor methods for higher-dimensional MR image reconstruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an important medical imaging modality widely used clinically to visualize soft-tissue structure and function in the human body. However, acquiring diagnostic quality MR images is a relatively slow process, and shortening MRI scan times is an important goal for reducing motion artifacts, improving clinical efficiency and patient comfort, and reducing cost. The long duration of MRI also forces a tradeoff between image spatial, temporal, and contrast resolution, and there are many potential applications where clinical requirements cannot be met by current protocols. Sparsity-driven reconstruction techniques are being increasingly employed to try and address these needs. However, MRI data commonly has auxiliary non-spatial dimensions (e.g., time, receiver channel), and sparse methods only efficiently exploit intra-dimensional redundancies. Calibration or training procedures are consequently used to identify and incorporate inter-dimensional redundancies into the reconstruction model. This comes at the expense of prolonged scan duration, error propagation, and limited experimental freedom.

This project focuses on the development of a robust, efficient, flexible, and totally calibration- and training-free framework for higher-dimensional MR image reconstruction. It is hypothesized that totally training-free MRI can be achieved by structuring image reconstruction as a low-rank matrix or tensor estimation problem that: 1) actively exploits inter-dimensional redundancies; 2) works complementarily with existing sparsity-based strategies; and 3) naturally generalizes for advanced imaging scenarios like non-Cartesian imaging. The first stage of the research focuses on building the mathematical foundation for this framework. The second stage focuses on practical realization, through development of efficient optimization strategies, high-performance code implementations, and automated parameter selection methodologies. These developments may lead to improved diagnoses, faster scanning, cost reduction, and the enablement of novel clinical MRI applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an important medical imaging modality widely used clinically to visualize soft-tissue structure and function in the human body. However, acquiring diagnostic quality MR images is a relatively slow process, and shortening MRI scan times is an important goal for reducing motion artifacts, improving clinical efficiency and patient comfort, and reducing cost. The long duration of MRI also forces a tradeoff between image spatial, temporal, and contrast resolution, and there are many potential applications where clinical requirements cannot be met by current protocols. Sparsity-driven reconstruction techniques are being increasingly employed to try and address these needs. However, MRI data commonly has auxiliary non-spatial dimensions (e.g., time, receiver channel), and sparse methods only efficiently exploit intra-dimensional redundancies. Calibration or training procedures are consequently used to identify and incorporate inter-dimensional redundancies into the reconstruction model. This comes at the expense of prolonged scan duration, error propagation, and limited experimental freedom.

This project focused on the development of a robust, efficient, flexible, and totally calibration- and training-free framework for higher-dimensional MR image reconstruction, based on structuring image reconstruction as a low-rank matrix or tensor estimation problem, particularly using so-called locally low-rank (LLR) methods. The first stage of the research focused on building the mathematical foundation for this framework. The second stage focused on practical realization, through development of efficient optimization strategies, high-performance code implementations, and automated parameter selection methodologies.

There were various theoretical advances throughout the scope of the project, leading to improved convergence of solutions, better understanding of the relative merits and behavior of different algorithms, and bounds on error rates. All of these developments are wholly general and not specific to MRI, even if that application was their motivation.  As such, these techniques can be used across a broad range of signal processing areas both within and outside of medical imaging.

There were also algorithmic advances to accelerate calculations, with the goal to drive calculation times down to levels that could be incorporated into a routine clinical workflow. For example, a high-performance implementation of our numerical optimization scheme for accelerated prostate cancer MR imaging, the theory and prototypes for which were developed under this award, was implemented (under separate funding) and incorporated into our clinical Radiology practice. It now provides reconstruction times on the order of a few minutes, which is faster than the acquisition time. Since July 2015, this technology has been used in >6500 patient exams, and has enabled improved pharmacokinetic staging and localization of prostate cancer.

To expand awareness and interest in these methods for MRI, Dr. Trzasko has continued to organize dedicated scientific sessions on this topic at the International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine (ISMRM) and SPIE Wavelets & Sparsity conferences. There is increasing awareness in the MRI community of the power of low-rank methods in general and of image-based LLR methods in particular. Several other research groups (e.g., Stanford Radiology) have already begun to adopt our low-rank methods and use them within their own developments. Demonstration software with test data has also been provided to several external research groups, who have since successfully incorporated these methods into their own applications. In March 2017, he also presented these methods to the lead software development team at General Electric’s MRI headquarters, in effort to step towards broader dissemination.

In general, the improvements in MRI reconstructions that are possible from our work may lead to improved diagnoses (from higher quality images due to reduction of motion artifacts and higher SNR), faster scanning (reducing health care costs), and the enablement of new clinical applications for MRI that require higher spatial and temporal resolution than is currently possible. This would benefit health care across the nation and the world.

In other areas, we also generalized our LLR denoising procedure to target applications with non-stationary noise, which has proven beneficial for our Ultrasound Research colleagues at Mayo. Our LLR methods now drive several planar wave imaging projects, ranging from in vivo dynamic microvasculature studies (e.g., for assessing kidney disease) to super-resolution to functional imaging. We developed several processing heuristics to reduce the computational cost of this technology and drive it towards real-time usage. We are currently working with one US commercial vendor (Verasonics) in effort to implement our methods within their commodity system, in effort to make the tools broadly available. We are also now collaborating with the CT group at Mayo to apply LLR-based methods for material decomposition from multi-energy CT data. We have also established relationships with machine learning scientists at the University of Minnesota, who have introduced these methods into their own communities.
